Previously, I bowed to the most supreme one, who is free from heat and benefits speech,
Whose words are in accord with the characteristics of the arhats who see reality and so forth.
Previously means first.
Bowed means to bow with pure faith.
Most supreme means the World-Honored One is the one who is worshipped by those who are worthy of offerings, and is also supreme among all dharmas, thus called most supreme.
Furthermore, the World-Honored One has attained mastery over all dharmas and all aspects, thus called most supreme.
Free from heat means free from burning.
It refers to the heat of afflictions that can burn the body and mind. The World-Honored One is free from them, thus called free from heat.
This is the accomplishment of one's own wisdom and cutting off.
That teacher said like this shows the TathÄgata's fulfillment of his own benefit.
Next, the words beneficial refer to the World-Honored One's speech, which is able to benefit all sentient beings.
Beneficial means peace and security.
Peace and security are synonyms for the same meaning.
This shows that the World-Honored One's benefiting others is complete.
This briefly explains that the Teacher of Gods and Humans has perfected the merit of benefiting himself and others.
The World-Honored One has brought both of those to ultimate completion, and therefore he is supreme among those worthy of offerings.

As for his speech is in accord with the characteristics, it means that the meaning of the principles is revealed in accord with such merits. The speech of the Teacher of Gods and Humans is in accord with this. Those who pay homage are said to pay homage to the Dharma Jewel.
Arhats who have seen the truth and so forth refer to those worthy of receiving offerings from gods, humans, and asuras, and are therefore called arhats.
This refers to those beyond training.
Truth refers to the four noble truths. Those in training who have seen [the truths] are called those who have seen the truth.
This only refers to those in training.
These in training and those beyond training and so forth refer to the supreme assembly.
Those who pay homage to them are said to pay homage to the Sangha Jewel.
Question:
Why pay homage?
Answer:
The Buddha opens the eye of wisdom, if one knows the various dharmas,
He also manifests for others, I will now speak a little.
The Buddha is one who knows all dharmas and knows all aspects, thus he is called the Buddha.
Opens the eye of wisdom means the meaning of the unobstructed eye of wisdom.
If refers to the dharmas spoken, revealed, proclaimed, and explained by the Buddha.
Knows means to understand.
Dharmas means to uphold, to uphold one's own nature, and to serve as a condition for others, thus they are called dharmas.
Dharmas have accumulated, thus they are called the assembly of dharmas.
The assembly of dharmas and the multitude of dharmas are one meaning with different names.
Also manifests for others means that having realized one's own benefit, one manifests for the sake of benefiting the world.
Some are aware but do not speak for others, as stated in the Ascending to the Forest of Åšaila SÅ«tra.

As for what I now say is a small part, among the dharmas taught by that Buddha, I now only speak of a small part of the characteristics of the dharmas, how could I be able to fully explain such meanings? Having said this,
it is asked:
What dharmas are taught by the Buddha that you wish to speak of?
It is answered:
Namely, with outflows and without outflows, with afflictions and without afflictions, with disputes and without disputes, with form and without form, etc., I will now explain.
All conditioned things with outflows are devoid of self, bliss, permanence, and purity.
This is because one does not see the outflows in regard to the self, etc.

As for all conditioned things with outflows are devoid of self, bliss, permanence, and purity, conditioned things with outflows are devoid of self, devoid of bliss, devoid of permanence, and devoid of purity.
The world is unable to contemplate this, obscured by ignorance and darkened by ignorance, and sees these four gates in a distorted manner, therefore it is called distorted.
It is asked:
How do we know that all contaminated activities are devoid of self?
The answer is:
Because the matter of self does not exist, it belongs to causes and conditions, therefore activities are called other, not the self-nature.
The one who conceives of self says:
My self does not belong to others.
Apart from this, there is no more, therefore the nature of self cannot be obtained.
Because there is no self, all activities are devoid of self.
The question is:
How do we know that all activities are devoid of pleasure?
The answer is:
Because they cause oppression.
All contaminated activities are the nature of suffering and also the conditions of suffering, therefore they oppress.
Oppression is called suffering, therefore they are devoid of pleasure.
The question is:
How do we know that all activities are devoid of permanence?
The answer is:
Because they arise and cease.
It is presently seen that all activities arise and then cease, there is no one who sees permanence, therefore they are devoid of permanence.
The question is:
How do we know that all contaminated activities are devoid of purity?
The answer is:
Because of the defilement of events.
The objects of the contaminated events are defiled by afflictions, therefore they are apart from purity.
Question:
In this way, these activities are apart from self and so forth. Why does the world grasp self and so forth?
Answer:
Because they do not see the contamination of self and so forth.
The contaminated activities are not seen as they really are. The world is unable to contemplate and understand self and so forth.

Just like an enemy hiding evil desires, deceptively speaking beautiful words and wandering in the household, actually not a friend but understanding it as a friend. Because of being covered by self and mine, one does not see non-self.
Therefore, seeing activities and so forth performing actions, because of delusion, in the matter of no self one sees self.

In order to counteract the covering of suffering, in the conceptualization of activities, abiding and so forth, one considers it to be happiness. Therefore, in the aggregate of suffering, one understands it as happiness.

The continuity of similar appearances covers up impermanent things. They see the continuity of similar appearances in the present, and remember past events and recite sutras and treatises. Therefore, they have the understanding of permanence in regard to impermanent phenomena.
The skin color covers up impure things. Therefore, they see a little purity in the places of hair, nails, teeth, etc., and have the understanding of purity in regard to impurity.
Although they see feces and urine, although they are impure, they still give rise to confusion:
Although this is impure, the rest should be pure.
It is just like a jackal looking at a kiá¹ƒÅ›uka flower.
Question:
Why does the treatise first discuss the four inversions?
Answer:
In order to know the characteristics of non-inversion.
I have already said that, in order to make disciples understand the truth, with a non-inverted mind, peacefully and easily, therefore the treatise first discusses the four inversions.
Question:
Are there only these dharmas apart from the self, etc., or are there any others?
Answer:
There is more.
If a place gives rise to afflictions, the sages say it is contaminated.
Because it is called contaminated, the wise say it is an affliction.

If a place gives rise to afflictions, the sages say it is contaminated. If it is a basis, a collection, a condition, or a sentient or non-sentient being, giving rise to afflictions such as the view of self, those dharmas are said to be contaminated.
Question:
Why is it so?
Answer:
Because it is called contaminated, the wise say it is an affliction.
Observing afflictions, they are called contaminated.
Because those dharmas give rise to afflictions, based on the arising of contamination, they are called contaminated, like a path of fear or poisoned food, and so on.

It should be said like this: if a matter belongs to contamination and is included in contamination, it is called contaminated. This refers to the contaminated giving rise to afflictions, not the uncontaminated dharmas belonging to afflictions and being included in afflictions. The uncontaminated dharmas only give rise to afflictions.
Question:
What is the meaning of outflows?
Answer:
From the peak of existence down to the uninterrupted hell, in between there are six sense bases that leak, therefore they are called outflows, just like a wound that leaks.
Also, because they cause one to remain in birth and death, they are called outflows.
Question:
Do they have other names?
Answer:
They do.
They are also called with afflictions, appropriated aggregates, and with conflict,
Because they arise from afflictions, appropriation, and conflict, their intrinsic nature is known through these explanations.
Those with outflows are also called with afflictions, appropriated aggregates, and with conflict.
Question:
Why are they called by those names?
Answer:ğŸ”½Because they arise from afflictions, appropriation, and conflict, their intrinsic nature is known through these explanations.
The outflows are synonymous with afflictions, appropriation, and conflict. They arise from afflictions, and they also give rise to afflictions, therefore they are called with afflictions.
In this way, it arises from grasping, and it also gives rise to grasping, so it is called with grasping.
It arises from disputes, and it also gives rise to disputes, so it is called with disputes.
Question:
Are the aggregates that the World-Honored One speaks of as the aggregates of grasping the same as the aggregates, or are there aggregates apart from the aggregates of grasping?
Answer:
If they are the aggregates of grasping, they are the same as the aggregates.
There may be aggregates that are not the aggregates of grasping.
Question:
Which ones are they?
Answer:
If the practices are free from afflictions, they are the uncontaminated aggregates.
And the previous aggregates of grasping are the aggregates spoken of by the sages.
If the practices are free from afflictions, they are the uncontaminated aggregates. These aggregates have another explanation.
There are two kinds of aggregates:
Uncontaminated and contaminated.
If the practices are free from the afflictions such as the view of self, they are called uncontaminated. They are aggregates but not the aggregates of grasping.

And the previously mentioned appropriated aggregates are the aggregates spoken of by the sages. If these uncontaminated aggregates and the previously mentioned appropriated aggregates are combined and spoken of as aggregates, they are the five aggregates such as form.
Question:
What is the meaning of the aggregates?
Answer:
The meaning of accumulation is the meaning of the aggregates.
Question:
If it is so, then the aggregates are only provisional names and do not have real entities.
Not only a single thing can be called an accumulation, because of their combination they are called an accumulation.
Answer:
Not only do they have characteristics, they also have real entities.
If there are these entities, then there are those characteristics, and therefore the aggregates have characteristics.
As the Buddha said, the characteristic of obstruction is the aggregate of form, and so on.
Therefore there are entities such as the realm of cognition, consciousness, afflictions, and so on, that are included.
Just like the four noble truths, therefore the aggregates have entities and are not only provisional names.
Question:
What are the differences between the aggregates, realms, bases, and so on?
Answer:
The ten kinds are called the form aggregate, also named non-indicative form,
This is the discrimination of the form aggregate, as taught by the World-Honored One.
Form has two kinds:
First, form that is an accumulation of atoms; second, form that is not an accumulation of atoms.
Form that is an accumulation of atoms refers to the ten form sense bases, from eye up to touch.
Form that is not an accumulation of atoms is called non-indicative form, included in the sense base of mental objects.
This will be explained in the chapter on karma.
All of these are the characteristics of the form aggregate, included in the category of the form aggregate, and are said to be the form aggregate by the Buddha.
Because it touches that, and that touches this, therefore it is called form.
Because it afflicts that, and that afflicts this.
As taught by the Buddha, like the touch of hands, etc., it is called form because of touch.
Question:
If it is like this, excluding non-indicative form, it is not form. Why is it not touchable by hands, etc.? Because it is unimpeded.
If you think that because the basis is tangible, and they are also tangible, there is no error, then feeling and so forth should also be form.
If you think that because the four great elements that are the basis are tangible, they are also tangible, we would say:
It is clearly seen that the work that needs to be done, such as painting and plastering, is like this. Then feeling and other mental factors should also be form.
Therefore you have an error.
They also rely on the eyes and other faculties, and they should also be tangible.
Answer:
It is not only the cause of the arising of mind and mental factors.

The mind and mental factors do not rely on the eyes and other faculties like light relies on a jewel. When they arise, the eyes and so forth act as causes, and in this way the eyes and so forth are tangible, but they are not tangible.
Furthermore, derivative form relies on the great elements, like light relies on a jewel. Therefore the great elements are tangible, and therefore they are also tangible.
Question:
Although it is explained like this, your characteristics are still not established.
Why is it so?
Because past and future subtle dust-like forms are excluded.
Answer:
The characteristics cannot be destroyed.
Past forms and touches have already ceased, and future forms are also like this in characteristics. Subtle dust is also touchable, but because it is too subtle, it cannot be known.
Therefore, all forms are touchable.
What is called the aggregate of consciousness is said to be the mental faculty,
And within the eighteen elements, it is also said to be the seven elements.

The aggregate of consciousness refers to the six groups of consciousness. Within the twelve sense bases, it is said to be the mental faculty. Within the eighteen elements, it is distinguished into the seven mental elements:

The eye-consciousness element, ear-consciousness element, nose-consciousness element, tongue-consciousness element, body-consciousness element, mind-consciousness element, and mind element.ğŸ”½Consciousness is able to cognize objects, therefore it is called consciousness.
Consciousness is the meaning of being able to grasp objects.
The remaining three aggregates, non-informative matter, and the three unconditioned dharmas,
Are said to be the dharma-Äyatana, and they are also the dharma-dhÄtu.
The dharmas such as feeling, etc., which were mentioned before, are collectively one dharma-Äyatana, and in the eighteen dhÄtus they are one dharma-dhÄtu.
The meaning of Äyatana is the meaning of gate, which is the meaning of Äyatana, like a window.
As the Buddha said:
Brahmin!
The eye is the gate, up to seeing forms.
The meaning of the character enter is the meaning of shu.
It can increase the mind and mental factors, and for this reason it is called an Äyatana.
The meaning of dhÄtu is the meaning of nature, which is the meaning of dhÄtu, like the dhÄtu of vermilion and the dhÄtu of realgar, etc.
The meaning of the character dhÄtu is that it can uphold its own characteristics and act as a condition for others, and for this reason it is called a dhÄtu.
There are seventeen of these dhÄtu matters, or twelve.
Why is it so?
Apart from the six consciousnesses, there is no separate mind element. Therefore, the seventeen are the six consciousnesses themselves, which continue in a series and are called the mind element.
Just as a father is called a son, and a son in turn continues in a series and is called a father.
In the same way, apart from the mind element there are no separate six consciousnesses. Therefore, there are twelve.
Because of the distinction between the basis and what is based on it, there are eighteen.
Those elements and sense bases include all dharmas, therefore those aggregates are only conditioned.
Question:
Why are the unconditioned dharmas not included in the aggregates?
Answer:
Because they do not have the characteristics of the aggregates.
There are two kinds of characteristics of the aggregates:
common characteristics and specific characteristics.
The common characteristics are the meaning of aggregation and impermanence, etc.
The specific characteristics are form's obstruction, etc.
These two kinds of characteristics do not exist in the unconditioned, therefore the unconditioned is not included.
What other meanings are there besides these?
They are not the basis for mistaken inversion and are the means of cessation.
Unconditioned phenomena are not the events of inversion, nor are they the means to eliminate inversion.

The aggregates are explained in terms of the events of inversion, while the uncontaminated aggregates are explained as the means to eliminate inversion. Therefore, the unconditioned is not included among the aggregates.
Thus, the aggregates, elements, and sense bases are established because their domains are the most extensive.
In order to explain various meanings, it is explained in this way.
One element is visible, ten elements are said to be resistant,
eight elements are indeterminate, the rest are either wholesome or unwholesome.
As for one element is visible, it should be known that one element among the eighteen elements is visible, namely the form element.
Why is that?
Because it is the domain of visual consciousness, therefore it is visible.
Moreover, it can be pointed out as this or that, therefore it is visible.
The remaining seventeen kinds are definitely not visible.

As for the ten realms that are said to have resistance, among the eighteen realms, the five internal realms, namely eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body, and the five external realms, namely form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, these ten realms are said to have resistance.
There are three kinds of resistance:
Namely, obstruction resistance, object resistance, and condition resistance.
Obstruction resistance means, for example, the left and right hands obstructing each other.
Object resistance means the faculties and objects resisting each other.
Condition resistance means the mental consciousness with regard to all dharmas.
Here, only obstruction resistance is taken, because they obstruct each other, and therefore are called resistant.
All those ten kinds of realms mutually resist each other. If it were not so, they would not increase.
As the elder KumÄralÄta said, When the mind wishes to arise, it is obstructed by others. One should know that this is resistance. The opposite is non-resistance.
The remaining eight realms definitely have no resistance.

The eight elements are indeterminate. It should be known that among the eighteen elements, the eight elements are indeterminate, namely the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, smell, taste, and touch elements.
They cannot be determined as having desirable or undesirable fruits, therefore they are indeterminate.

The remaining ones are wholesome and unwholesome. The remaining ten elements are said to be indeterminate, wholesome, and unwholesome, namely the form, sound, body, speech, and mind elements. These are wholesome and unwholesome.
Why is this?
Because they arise from wholesome and unwholesome minds.
The remaining ones are indeterminate.
The seven mind elements such as eye consciousness are wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate.ğŸ”½The dharmas associated with mind element are wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate.
The dharmas associated with mind element are wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate by their intrinsic nature.
Those wholesome by their intrinsic nature are shame, conscience, and the three roots of wholesomeness such as non-greed.
Those wholesome by association are associated with those feelings and other mental factors.
The nature of unwholesomeness refers to the three roots of unwholesomeness such as greed, etc., which are shamelessness and lack of conscience.
The unwholesomeness of association refers to the mental factors such as feeling, etc., which are associated with them.
The indeterminate is contrary to both of these.
The dissociated dharmas will be discussed in the Miscellaneous Chapter.
Among the unconditioned, one is wholesome and two are indeterminate. The conditioned by causes is wholesome, and space and cessation not due to deliberation are indeterminate.
Among them, that which includes the wholesome is the fruit of love and peace, and is therefore called wholesome.
That which includes the wholesome refers to the truth of the path and a part of the truths of suffering and origination.
The fruit of love refers to a part of the truths of suffering and origination.
Peace refers to the truth of cessation.
That which is contrary to this is called unwholesome.

That which is neither wholesome nor unwholesome is called indeterminate. That which is neither wholesome nor unwholesome cannot be indicated as wholesome or unwholesome, and is therefore called indeterminate;
that which has no fruit that can be indicated is also called indeterminate.
Fifteen are definitely contaminated, the rest are of three kinds, and three have three kinds.
The intermediate existence of the desire realm has four, eleven in the two existences.
The fifteen that are definitely contaminated are the five internal realms, the five external realms, and the five consciousness realms. These fifteen realms are entirely contaminated.
The other two are the remaining three realms:
The mind realm, the dharma realm, and the mind consciousness realm, etc.
They have two kinds:
Contaminated and uncontaminated.
The contaminated are those that are associated with the arising of contaminants, co-contaminants, and the fulfillment of traces, and are therefore called contaminated.
Those that are contrary to this are called uncontaminated.

In brief, the unknown-and-desired-to-be-known faculty and other uncontaminated faculties, the dharmas that arise together with them and their attainment, the supramundane liberation attainment, and the unconditioned are uncontaminated;
The rest are contaminated.
The three threes are the three realms that can be found within the three existences.

The four of the desire realm are the realms of smell, taste, nose consciousness, and tongue consciousness, which are exclusively categorized as belonging to the desire realm, because they do not have the craving for the food of form in the form realm.

The eleven in two realms are the five internal realms, the realms of form, sound, and touch, and the three consciousnesses that take them as objects. These eleven exist in the desire realm and the form realm, but not in the formless realm, because there is no form.

They are bound by the passions of the desire realm and are thus bound to the desire realm; they are bound by the passions of the form realm and are thus bound to the form realm; they are bound by the passions of the formless realm and are thus bound to the formless realm.
Five have initial and sustained thought; three are of three kinds; the rest are without.
Seven have objects; also part of the dharma realm should be understood as having objects.
The five realms of consciousness are exclusively with initial and sustained thought, because they are associated with initial and sustained thought.
The three kinds of three are the realms of mind, dharmas, and mental consciousness. They are of three kinds:

In the desire realm and first dhyÄna there is initial thought and sustained thought. In the intermediate dhyÄna there is no initial thought but there is sustained thought. In the second dhyÄna and above up to the peak of existence there is neither initial thought nor sustained thought.
As for the dharma realm having initial thought and sustained thought, in the desire realm and in the Brahma world excluding the mind and mental factors of initial thought and sustained thought,
as for the dharma realm without initial thought but with sustained thought, in the intermediate dhyÄna excluding the mental factors of sustained thought,
as for the dharma realm without initial thought and without sustained thought, in the second dhyÄna and above up to the peak of existence the mental factors of the dharma realm.

In the intermediate dhyÄna, sustained thought, all non-informative, and the dissociated dharma realm, in the desire realm and Brahma world sustained thought, are not included in these three. If one wishes to explain them, one should say they are without sustained thought but with initial thought.
As for the rest being without, the remaining ten realms are without initial thought and without sustained thought, because they are not associated with initial thought and sustained thought.

It should be known that the seven [mental] realms and a part of the dharma realm also have objects. The seven mental realms and the dharma realm of mental factors have objects. Because they have this condition, they are called having objects. Because they have objects that can be grasped, they are said to have objects.
There are also other conditions called means, such as means of a staff, and so on. These are worldly conventional expressions.
It should be known that the other [means] definitely do not have conditions.
Nine are not received, the other two are both conditioned and unconditioned,
and one is only conditioned. It should be known that the seventeen elements are all conditioned.
As for nine are not received, the nine elements are definitely not called received.

If form is counted as a faculty or is not separated from a faculty, or if mind and mental factors are cut off and destroyed, then feeling abides within them. If they are different, they are not received.
Those seven mind elements, sound element, and dharma element - these nine elements are called not received, because they are not the abode of mind and mental factors.

As for the other two, the other nine elements are of two kinds. The five internal elements, if in the present, are called received, or this present consciousness, although empty, is also called with feeling, because that kind is categorized as sentient beings, therefore it is said to be received.
Past, future, and that which is not sentient is called non-receiving.
Form, smell, taste, and touch that are not separated from the faculties, in the present, are called receiving, just as the mind and mental factors abide in the middle of the faculties.
The rest is called non-receiving.
In brief, if a dharma arises but has not yet ceased, is sentient, is resistant, can be pulled, and can be pushed, it is called receiving.
That which has arisen but has not yet ceased excludes the past and future.
Sentient excludes the present that is not sentient.
Resistant excludes that which has arisen but not yet ceased.
Mind and mental factors that can be pulled and pushed excludes the sound element.
The one of conditioned and unconditioned means that because of the combination of causes and conditions, it is called conditioned, which means the meaning of being able to produce.
What is the agent?
It means having a cause.
Having a cause means having conditioning factors, and because of having conditioning factors, it is called conditioned.
The one dharma realm includes both conditioned and unconditioned. Among them, the three kinds of permanence are unconditioned:
Space, cessation through discernment, and cessation not through discernment.
The three aggregates of feeling, etc., and unconditioned form are conditioned, and are exclusively conditioned.
One should know that the remaining seventeen realms have causes, and are exclusively conditioned.
Question:
Thus the characteristics of dharmas have been analyzed.
How are dharmas subsumed?
Are they subsumed by their own nature or by the nature of others?
Answer:
Dharmas are apart from the nature of others, each abiding in its own nature.
Therefore, all dharmas are subsumed by their own nature.
Dharmas are apart from the nature of others means the eye is apart from the ear.
In this way, if the characteristics of all things are subsumed by their own nature, this is said to be inappropriate, and therefore they are not subsumed by the nature of others.
What fault is there in that?
If one arises and ceases, then all the rest would also arise and cease.
This is not reasonable, therefore other natures do not include.
Each abides in its own nature, the eye abides in the nature of the eye, and so do all dharmas.
Therefore, all dharmas are included in their own natures, therefore their own natures include all dharmas.
This is the meaning of the inclusion of specific characteristics explained by this master.
This is also of two kinds:
arising and delimitation.
As for arising, the form aggregate includes the ten form sense bases up to form included in the dharma sense base, and the eye sense base includes the eye sense base.
As for delimitation, this single moment includes a single moment, not other moments.
If other inclusions are mentioned, such as a pavilion including its foundation, eaves, beams, rafters, etc., this is conventional speech.
That the eye sense base is included in one element, one sense base, and one aggregate, one should know that all dharmas are also like this.
Chapter on Action, Chapter 2. The characteristics of dharmas have already been explained. The distinctions in arising will now be discussed.
Question:
If the nature of all dharmas is included, can they also be born by their own power?
Answer:
At first, there is no single one that can give birth, because it is apart from companions.
All of them, each with its own power, dharmas are then able to be born.

At first, there is no single one that can give birth, because it is apart from companions means that the nature of conditioned activities is weak, therefore no dharma is able to give birth by its own power.
Question:
How can they be born?
Answer:
All of them, each with its own power, dharmas are then able to be born means that conditioned dharmas are born with each one's own power, like two weak people rising up with each other's power.
These conditioned activities are briefly said to be of four kinds: form, mind, mental factors, and factors not directly associated with the mind.
Their birth also has four kinds:
making, taking, making a basis, making a dominant condition, and making companions.
Their making means the fruit of dependence, the fruit of retribution, and a small part of the fruit of the human being.
As support, the elements and six sense bases are the four great elements that form matter.
As dominant, in a single moment of arising, all dharmas.
As companions, mind and mental factors are companions to each other, as well as the characteristics of conditioned phenomena.
I will first explain the conditioned phenomena that arise as companions with the mind.ğŸ”½Where there is the arising of mind,
it definitely arises together with mental factors,
the aggregate of mental factors, and also with non-associated compositional factors.
Mind refers to the same meaning expressed by different names: mind, thought, and consciousness.
This mind is distinguished by goodness, etc., by realm, by type, by basis, and by being uncontaminated, etc., with innumerable distinctions.
This mind, whether in terms of basis, object, or moment of arising, definitely arises together with mental factors, and also with compositional factors not associated with the mind.
Question:
What are the mental factors?
Answer:
Conception, desire, contact, wisdom, mindfulness, thought, liberation,
Attention, on the object, samÄdhi, feeling, and so forth.
Conception is the ability to grasp characteristics of the object, such as grasping the characteristics of male, female, coarse, fine, stump, long, short, etc.
Desire is fondness, such as seeing one's own happiness, etc.
Contact is the union of the mind with the object, like the union of sunlight and a jewel giving rise to fire.
Wisdom is the ability to know the object, such as this is form, not taste, not this, etc.
Mindfulness is fixing the mind on the object.
Thought is the movement of the mind in the wholesome, unwholesome, or neutral.
Liberation is the unimpeded movement of the mind on the object.
Attention is the vigor in grasping the object.
Some say:
It is the meaning of the mind being focused.
SamÄdhi is the mind not being distracted when grasping the object.
Feeling is the experience in pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral objects.
The arising of all minds is said to be the arising of the holy ones,
Turning together on a single object, and also always associated.
As for the arising of all minds is said to be the arising of the holy ones, these ten dharmas such as conceptualization arise together with all minds, and are therefore called the great grounds;
They are the great ground of mind, and are therefore called the great grounds.
As for turning together on a single object, these ten dharmas turn together with all minds on a single object, and do not turn on separate objects.
There are five kinds of sameness, namely appearance, object, time, basis, and matter, with the same appearance, the same object, the same time, the same basis, and the same matter.
Sameness means the meaning of being mutually associated.
As for also always associated, they are always associated with the mind, and arise together with it, and are associated with grasping the object, and are therefore called associated.
The dharmas that are associated with all minds have already been explained. The dharmas that are not associated with all minds will now be explained.
The faculties are shame, conscience, faith, tranquility, non-negligence,
Non-harming, vigor, equanimity, or heat, and applied and sustained thought.
